title: Sydney Northern Beaches council rakes in $7.7 million in parking fines
text:
A Sydney council has pocketed over $20million worth of parking fines in the past three years - raking in $7.7million in just the last 12 months.

The Northern Beaches Council handed out over 60,000 fines related to a number of offences and parking infringements were the biggest source of profit within the past financial year.

Councillor Vincent De Luca said the revenue was going towards increasing the number of council directors, who are being paid six-figure salaries.

The Northern Beaches Council handed out over 60,000 fines related to a number of offences and parking infringements were the biggest source of profit within the past financial year

'Our CEO is on nearly $500,000 a year,' Councillor De Luca told The Manly Daily.

'The CEO doubled the number of directors from three to six and they are all on $300-$400,000 a year.'

Council CEO Ray Brownlee said the high revenue gained from fines was due to the council being the fourth-largest local government area in NSW.

Parking was always in high demand and therefore restrictions are in place to allow all motorists a chance to secure a spot.

NRMA spokesman Peter Khoury said the money should be focused on road repairs.

While Mr Khoury said motorists should be obeying parking rules, he said they shouldn't be 'used as cash cows'.

'It's about making sure people don't abuse parking rules and not about just making money off families. Motorists should not be used as cash cows,' Mr Khoury said.

Council CEO Ray Brownlee said the high revenue gained from fines was due to the council being the fourth largest local government area in NSW (file image of Sydney's Northern Beaches)

But the Northern Beaches Mayor defended the council, saying the fines were going towards helping better the community.

Mayor Michael Regan said more than $2million went towards youth and community services while another $5million went to sports facilities.

The council also said that a staggering $14million had been spent on maintaining roads, footpaths and kerbs during the financial year.

But data from Your Council showed that the Northern Beaches council had spent half the money of other Sydney areas on roads and bridges between the 2017/2018 financial year.

Within the area, 900 complaints were lodged due to wheel damage and busted tyres because of 60 reported potholes.
